ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Practical, theoretical, ethical introduction to conducting field research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The textbook could be much better integrated into the classroom and there could be a more ongoing infrastructure for students to share and collaborate on projects rather than simply going off to research their own aspects of a language. Claire is an excellent shepherd through the beginnings of field work, though.
Assignment expectations and deadlines could be clearer, but feedback was very helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Hard to say, if youre a linguistics major its definitely important to expose yourself to.

This is a great course for students who want to learn how to apply linguistics concepts to real-world situations and get to know friendly native speaker consultants and do work that has meaningful impact.
